last_200_tokens: - Sudden loss of renal function (HP:0011034) - Shoulder dystocia (HP:0011413) - Decreased triglycerides in blood (HP:0030502) - Prolonged/excessive menses and bleeding at irregular intervals (HP:0400008) Key findings about candidate genes: - SLC37A4 (ENSG00000137700): Associated with glycogen storage diseases, particularly Glycogen Storage Disease I (von Gierke disease) - this is highly relevant to the metabolic phenotype of increased homocystine in urine and could explain the multi-system involvement - BCOR (ENSG00000183337): Associated with microphthalmia syndromic 2, which is X-linked dominant and more focused on developmental/structural abnormalities - Other genes had associations with specific diseases but less relevance to the comprehensive phenotype profile The STRING database enrichment analysis showed SLC37A4 has very strong associations with: - Glycogen storage disease (p-value: 2.2e-17, fdr: 1.01e-13) - Glycogen storage disease I (p-value: 3.67e-12, fdr: 5.62e-09) - Inherited metabolic disorder (p-value: 4.35e-09, fdr: 3.99e-06) - Glucose-6-phosphate transport (p-value: 1.1e-11, fdr: 1.73e-07) SLC37A4 encodes the glucose-6-phosphate exchanger, which is critical for glucose homeostasis and plays a role in multiple metabolic processes. Glycogen storage diseases can present with seizures, neurological symptoms, and multi-system involvement, which matches the patient's phenotype profile. Given all this evidence, SLC37A4 (ENSG00000137700) appears to be the most likely causal gene.</think> <solution> {'causal_gene': ['ENSG00000137700']} </solution>
